title: When creating a song which is made first, the music or the vocals? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is dependent on the song. Essentially these days you have top line writers and you have track writers. The top line writer will probably be a vocalist with a good ear for melody and an ability to write good lyrics. They might have a little book of incomplete lyrics and song ideas they carry around with them. They might also have a dictaphone that they sing melody ideas into when they are driving, doing chores etc etc. A track writer will be more production oriented and might have a back catalogue of tracks in different genres he can whip out in a writing session. So a song could start with either. Sometimes, songs start with the title because it provides an overall theme and keeps the lyricist on track without splintering off down tangents.

Well, Achira, it depends on what a songwriter baseline is - and by that I mean, whether he/she is a lyricist (poet) or a musician. But most songwriters start with a hook or a melody, then fit lyrics to it, vice the other way around. Why? Because it is a more structured song that way. In other words, if I write a poem then want to fit music to it, I have to be musically prepared for different progressions or variations in the song because the syllable beat may not be exactly the same from line to line. But laying down a melody first allows the lyricist to hear the beats and create the words around it, usually a more structured song.
